#Text=CHAPTER VI .
#Text=IT'S A CARAVAN
#Text=I WAS so weak that the only thing I wanted was a chance to lay down , so I made straight for my locker-bunk , and stretched myself out there .
#Text=But a body could n't get back his strength in no such oven as that , so Tom give the command to soar , and Jim started her aloft .
#Text=We had to go up a mile before we struck comfortable weather where it was breezy and pleasant and just right , and pretty soon I was all straight again .
#Text=Tom had been setting quiet and thinking ; but now he jumps up and says :
#Text=“ I bet you a thousand to one I know where we are .
#Text=We 're in the Great Sahara , as sure as guns ! ”
#Text=He was so excited he could n't hold still ; but I was n't .
#Text=I says :
#Text=“ Well , then , where 's the Great Sahara ?
#Text=In England or in Scotland ? ”
#Text=“ ' Tai n't in either ; it 's in Africa . ”
#Text=Jim 's eyes bugged out , and he begun to stare down with no end of interest , because that was where his originals come from ; but I did n't more than half believe it .
#Text=I could n't , you know ; it seemed too awful far away for us to have traveled .
#Text=But Tom was full of his discovery , as he called it , and said the lions and the sand meant the Great Desert , sure .
#Text=He said he could ' a ' found out , before we sighted land , that we was crowding the land somewheres , if he had thought of one thing ; and when we asked him what , he said :
#Text=“ These clocks .
#Text=They 're chronometers .
#Text=You always read about them in sea voyages .
#Text=One of them is keeping Grinnage time , and the other is keeping St. Louis time , like my watch .
#Text=When we left St. Louis it was four in the afternoon by my watch and this clock , and it was ten at night by this Grinnage clock .
#Text=Well , at this time of the year the sun sets at about seven o'clock .
#Text=Now I noticed the time yesterday evening when the sun went down , and it was half-past five o'clock by the Grinnage clock , and half past 11 A.M. by my watch and the other clock .

#Text=You see , the sun rose and set by my watch in St. Louis , and the Grinnage clock was six hours fast ; but we 've come so far east that it comes within less than half an hour of setting by the Grinnage clock now , and I 'm away out -- more than four hours and a half out .
#Text=You see , that meant that we was closing up on the longitude of Ireland , and would strike it before long if we was p'inted right -- which we was n't .
#Text=No , sir , we 've been a-wandering -- wandering ' way down south of east , and it 's my opinion we are in Africa .
#Text=Look at this map . You see how the shoulder of Africa sticks out to the west .
#Text=Think how fast we 've traveled ; if we had gone straight east we would be long past England by this time .
#Text=You watch for noon , all of you , and we 'll stand up , and when we ca n't cast a shadow we 'll find that this Grinnage clock is coming mighty close to marking twelve .
#Text=Yes , sir , I think we 're in Africa ; and it 's just bully . ”
#Text=Jim was gazing down with the glass .
#Text=He shook his head and says :
#Text=“ Mars Tom , I reckon dey 's a mistake som'er 's , hai n't seen no niggers yit . ”
#Text=“ That 's nothing ; they do n't live in the desert .
#Text=What is that , ' way off yonder ?
#Text=Gimme a glass . ”
#Text=He took a long look , and said it was like a black string stretched across the sand , but he could n't guess what it was .

#Text=“ Well , ” I says , “ I reckon maybe you 've got a chance now to find out whereabouts this balloon is , because as like as not that is one of these lines here , that 's on the map , that you call meridians of longitude , and we can drop down and look at its number , and -- ”
#Text=“ Oh , shucks , Huck Finn , I never see such a lunkhead as you .
#Text=Did you s'pose there 's meridians of longitude on the EARTH ? ”
#Text=“ Tom Sawyer , they 're set down on the map , and you know it perfectly well , and here they are , and you can see for yourself . ”
#Text=“ Of course they 're on the map , but that 's nothing ; there ai n't any on the GROUND . ”
#Text=“ Tom , do you know that to be so ? ”
#Text=“ Certainly I do . ”
#Text=“ Well , then , that map 's a liar again .
#Text=I never see such a liar as that map . ”

#Text=He fired up at that , and I was ready for him , and Jim was warming his opinion , too , and next minute we 'd ' a ' broke loose on another argument , if Tom had n't dropped the glass and begun to clap his hands like a maniac and sing out :
#Text=“ Camels ! -- Camels ! ”
#Text=So I grabbed a glass and Jim , too , and took a look , but I was disappointed , and says :
#Text=“ Camels your granny ; they 're spiders . ”
#Text=“ Spiders in a desert , you shad ?
#Text=Spiders walking in a procession ? You do n't ever reflect , Huck Finn , and I reckon you really have n't got anything to reflect WITH .
#Text=Do n't you know we 're as much as a mile up in the air , and that that string of crawlers is two or three miles away ?
#Text=Spiders , good land ! Spiders as big as a cow ?
#Text=Perhaps you 'd like to go down and milk one of ' em .
#Text=But they 're camels , just the same .
#Text=It 's a caravan , that 's what it is , and it 's a mile long . ”
